d29_u6.therapist_prev_utt: Yeah. d29_u6.therapist_utt: Um, many people find that when then- when they are restricting their intake or starting some, uh, ac-activity patterns that are really rigorous, that, um, a piece of their mental health suffers because they start to obsess, um, more than they'd like to be about those things. So, my approach with clients is just a more holistic approach. Looking at certainly some behavior changes that you could make to be more physically active, improve your energy levels. Um, and also look at activities that enhance your mood. We can also take a look at some dietary patterns and see if-if there are ways you could tweak how you're fueling your body throughout the day, but at the same time, sort of letting go of what happens on the scale. book_d11.client_utt: I know I’m supposed to work out all the time, but it’s too hard to stick with it, so I don’t even know why I bother.

book_d11.summary: The client expresses frustration and defeat regarding their inability to stick with working out, indicating resistance to making a positive behavior change.

book_d12.client_prev_utt: I know I’m supposed to work out all the time, but it’s too hard to stick with it, so I don’t even know why I bother.

book_d12.summary: The client is open to the idea of making a positive behavior change regarding their exercise routine. They acknowledge the benefits of exercising and express a desire to experience those benefits again. The client seems ready to make a change.

book_d14.client_prev_utt: I’m tired of feeling so tired all the time. So I’m really hoping you can help me change my diet. I’m willing to do whatever it takes. Just give me a plan and I’ll do it!

book_d15.client_prev_utt: I just don’t think I’m getting the nutrition I need since I eat out all the time. I want to be healthier.

book_d15.client_utt: I’d probably have to start cooking more. I’m a pretty decent cook, I’ve just gotten lazy lately and it has been easier to eat out. But the foods I’m eating at restaurants are not the healthiest and I always leave restaurants feeling sluggish and bloated.

book_d22.client_utt: I’m just here because my doctor told me he wanted me to try changing my diet before he puts me on those drugs to lower my cholesterol.
book_d22.therapist_utt: OK, so you’re here because your doctor referred you for help lowering your cholesterol through diet and exercise. How do you feel about being here?

sub_behaviours.reflection-simple: OK, so you’re here because your doctor referred you for help lowering your cholesterol through diet and exercise.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: How do you feel about being here?

book_d22.summary: The client appears open to making a positive behavior change in their diet to lower their cholesterol levels, as suggested by their doctor. They seem ready to take action towards improving their health.

book_d23.client_prev_utt: I’m just here because my doctor told me he wanted me to try changing my diet before he puts me on those drugs to lower my cholesterol.
book_d23.therapist_prev_utt: OK, so you’re here because your doctor referred you for help lowering your cholesterol through diet and exercise. How do you feel about being here?
book_d23.client_utt: I don’t know. He doesn’t know that I already tried making changes a year ago when I was with my last doctor and it was impossible.
book_d23.therapist_utt: You tried making changes on your own; you obviously care about your health. Tell me more about that.

sub_behaviours.affirm: You tried making changes on your own; you obviously care about your health.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: Tell me more about that.

book_d23.summary: The client is resistant to making a positive behavior change, as they feel that previous attempts to change their diet were unsuccessful. They are unsure about being in therapy and may not be fully ready to commit to making changes at this time.

book_d24.client_prev_utt: I don’t know. He doesn’t know that I already tried making changes a year ago when I was with my last doctor and it was impossible.
book_d24.therapist_prev_utt: You tried making changes on your own; you obviously care about your health. Tell me more about that.
book_d24.client_utt: Yeah, it’s not like I want a heart attack or anything. I just don’t have time to eat all perfect, so I wish he’d just give me those drugs already.
book_d24.therapist_utt: You’re aware of the risks of high cholesterol and having a heart attack is one risk that concerns you.
book_d24.summary: The client appears resistant to making a positive behavior change, as they express frustration with past attempts and a desire for a quick fix solution. They seem focused on the barriers to change, such as lack of time, and are more interested in medication than making lifestyle changes.

book_d25.client_prev_utt: Yeah, it’s not like I want a heart attack or anything. I just don’t have time to eat all perfect, so I wish he’d just give me those drugs already.
book_d25.therapist_prev_utt: You’re aware of the risks of high cholesterol and having a heart attack is one risk that concerns you.
book_d25.client_utt: Yeah, I would like to stick around a little longer. I’m good at popping pills. It’s the whole cooking thing that gets me. Plus, I like food, and I like to eat and you’re just going to tell me to stop eating, or something.
book_d25.therapist_utt: You’re someone who is consistent when it comes to taking medication, so you feel that might be your most viable option at this point. You’re concerned that making changes to lower your cholesterol would involve having to eliminate foods you like. You seem to care about your health and want to improve your cholesterol. I appreciate your honesty in sharing some reservations you had about seeing me today. Some of my clients have found that by making a few small changes, they’ve been able to lower their cholesterol without having to revamp their entire diets. Even making a few small changes can be hard, though. Ultimately, it’s your choice what you’d like to do.

sub_behaviours.summarise: You’re someone who is consistent when it comes to taking medication, so you feel that might be your most viable option at this point. You’re concerned that making changes to lower your cholesterol would involve having to eliminate foods you like. You seem to care about your health and want to improve your cholesterol. I appreciate your honesty in sharing some reservations you had about seeing me today.
sub_behaviours.emphasize-autonomy: Some of my clients have found that by making a few small changes, they’ve been able to lower their cholesterol without having to revamp their entire diets. Even making a few small changes can be hard, though. Ultimately, it’s your choice what you’d like to do.

book_d25.summary: The client is aware of the risks associated with high cholesterol and is concerned about having a heart attack. They express a desire to live longer but are resistant to making changes to their diet and prefer taking medication instead. The client is not fully ready to make a positive behavior change at this time.

book_d27.client_prev_utt: You can help me by telling my doctor just to give me those pills!

book_d31.client_prev_utt: I have this new girlfriend who’s pretty special. We really have a good time together. And things are just getting good, so I don’t want to die on her.
book_d31.therapist_prev_utt: There’s someone special in your life who might miss you.

sub_behaviours.affirm: You’re excited to start making some positive changes in your eating patterns.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What concerns do you have about how this might go?

book_d44.summary: The client appears ready to make a positive behavior change by purchasing diet shakes to help with weight loss.

book_d45.client_prev_utt: I just need to drink those diet shakes for breakfast and lunch. Then, no matter what I have for dinner, I’ll still lose weight. I’ve already gone to the store and bought a batch of them. They’re really good.

book_d45.therapist_utt: You’ve noticed in the short term that you lose weight when sticking to a diet with meal replacement shakes. What was it about this eating plan that made you stop?

sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What was it about this eating plan that made you stop?

book_d46.client_prev_utt: None, really. I’ve tried diets like this before and I seem to lose a lot of weight in a short amount of time. So it does work.
book_d46.therapist_prev_utt: You’ve noticed in the short term that you lose weight when sticking to a diet with meal replacement shakes. What was it about this eating plan that made you stop?
book_d46.client_utt: I think I just wasn’t motivated enough last time. I’m newly single and so I really need to lose this weight since I need to get out there and start dating again.
book_d46.therapist_utt: You’re anxious to start seeing some results. However, I have a concern about the approach you’ve chosen. Can I share my concern with you?

sub_behaviours.reflection-simple: You’re anxious to start seeing some results.
sub_behaviours.persuade: However, I have a concern about the approach you’ve chosen. Can I share my concern with you?

book_d46.summary: The client appears to be ready to make a positive behavior change in order to lose weight and start dating again. They have previously experienced success with diets but lacked motivation to continue. The client's current motivation stems from their desire to improve their dating prospects.

book_d47.client_prev_utt: I think I just wasn’t motivated enough last time. I’m newly single and so I really need to lose this weight since I need to get out there and start dating again.
book_d47.therapist_prev_utt: You’re anxious to start seeing some results. However, I have a concern about the approach you’ve chosen. Can I share my concern with you?
book_d47.therapist_utt: I’m concerned that this dieting plan could be too restrictive. Researchers consistently show that weight-loss plans based on diet shakes help people lose weight in the short term but end with regaining the weight in the long run. Some of my clients have also experienced feelings of failure and body dissatisfaction following these types of plans. They often get tired of drinking the shakes over time. Of course, you’re the expert on your body, so it’s up to you what you choose to do. I just want to make sure you have all the information before you make your decision. What do you think about what I’ve just shared?

sub_behaviours.give-information: I’m concerned that this dieting plan could be too restrictive. Researchers consistently show that weight-loss plans based on diet shakes help people lose weight in the short term but end with regaining the weight in the long run. Some of my clients have also experienced feelings of failure and body dissatisfaction following these types of plans. They often get tired of drinking the shakes over time.
sub_behaviours.emphasize-autonomy: Of course, you’re the expert on your body, so it’s up to you what you choose to do. I just want to make sure you have all the information before you make your decision.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What do you think about what I’ve just shared?

book_d47.summary: The client is showing readiness to make a positive behavior change by acknowledging the need to lose weight in order to start dating again. The therapist is expressing concern about the client's approach, indicating a potential resistance to change.

book_d48.therapist_prev_utt: In your efforts to switch over to a vegetarian diet, you mentioned a desire to add more protein-rich foods to your dinner meals. We’ve discussed a few ideas. Which ideas appeal to you the most?

book_d56.therapist_prev_utt: You’ve mentioned an interest in trying to include an afternoon snack each workday. How confident are you on a scale from 0 to 10 that you can make this change, with 0 being not at all confident and 10 being very confident?

book_d81.therapist_utt: You’re a little unsure about how to prepare them and incorporate them into your meals and snacks.
book_d81.summary: The client appears hesitant and unsure about making a positive behavior change. They do not seem ready to take action towards adding more vegetables to their diet.

book_d82.client_prev_utt: I don’t know. I’ve never done much with them before.
book_d82.therapist_prev_utt: You’re a little unsure about how to prepare them and incorporate them into your meals and snacks.
book_d82.client_utt: My sister has me over for dinner sometimes. One time she made a stir fry that I really liked. I guess I could ask her how she does it.
book_d82.therapist_utt: You’re not afraid to ask for help. And you’re even willing to move out of your comfort zone and learn and try new things.
book_d82.summary: The client appears hesitant but open to the idea of incorporating new healthy foods into their diet. They are seeking guidance and support from their sister to make positive changes.

book_d83.client_utt: Thinking about what and when to eat is a constant stress and some days I’m just too tired.
book_d83.therapist_utt: You’ve been through a lot, and some days it wears you down; you’re here today because you’re not ready to give up.
book_d83.summary: The client expresses feeling overwhelmed and stressed about making decisions about food choices and meal times, indicating some resistance to making a positive behavior change. No clear readiness for change is detected in the dialogue.

book_d84.client_prev_utt: Thinking about what and when to eat is a constant stress and some days I’m just too tired.
book_d84.therapist_prev_utt: You’ve been through a lot, and some days it wears you down; you’re here today because you’re not ready to give up.
book_d84.client_utt: I can’t give up. I have to do this.
book_d84.therapist_utt: Tell me more about why this is important to you.
book_d84.summary: The client is showing signs of readiness to make a positive behavior change in their eating habits, despite feeling stressed and tired at times. They express determination and commitment to not giving up on their goal.

book_d85.client_utt: I don’t even know what I’m supposed to be doing here.
book_d85.therapist_utt: You’re unsure about your purpose here today.
book_d85.summary: The client appears to be resistant to making a positive behavior change, as they express confusion and uncertainty about the purpose of the session. No clear attitude towards behavior change is detected.

book_d86.client_prev_utt: I don’t even know what I’m supposed to be doing here.
book_d86.therapist_prev_utt: You’re unsure about your purpose here today.
book_d86.client_utt: No, I know I have to get my cholesterol down. I don’t know what you’re going to do about it.
book_d86.therapist_utt: You’re used to doing things on your own.
book_d86.summary: The client is aware of the need to lower their cholesterol but is unsure about the therapist's role in helping them achieve this goal. The client may be open to making a positive behavior change but is currently feeling uncertain about the process.

book_d87.client_prev_utt: No, I know I have to get my cholesterol down. I don’t know what you’re going to do about it.
book_d87.therapist_prev_utt: You’re used to doing things on your own.
book_d87.client_utt: Well if I don’t, no one else will.
book_d87.therapist_utt: You’re right, it is completely up to you. I can help if you’d like my help. What’s the best use of our time together today?

sub_behaviours.emphasize-autonomy: You’re right, it is completely up to you.
sub_behaviours.seek-collaboration: I can help if you’d like my help. What’s the best use of our time together today?

book_d87.summary: The client appears ready to make a positive behavior change in regards to their cholesterol levels, as they acknowledge the need to lower it. However, they may still have some resistance as they are used to handling things on their own.

book_d88.client_utt: I was just so much better at this when I did it before.
book_d88.summary: The client expresses a sense of nostalgia or longing for a time when they were more successful in a certain behavior. This could indicate some readiness for change, as they are reflecting on past successes.

book_d89.client_prev_utt: I was just so much better at this when I did it before.
book_d89.client_utt: I could get up in the morning and exercise first thing.
book_d89.therapist_utt: You were able to make exercise a top priority.
book_d89.summary: The client appears to have a positive attitude towards making a behavior change, as they reminisce about a time when they were successful in exercising regularly. They seem ready to make a positive change in their behavior.

book_d90.client_prev_utt: I could get up in the morning and exercise first thing.
book_d90.therapist_prev_utt: You were able to make exercise a top priority.
book_d90.client_utt: Well, I just knew it would make me feel better, and it really did. My therapist used to beg me to exercise. I felt like it worked better than my meds. I even slept better.
book_d90.therapist_utt: Exercising keeps your energy levels up and helps to subdue the depression, keeping you in a healthier place.
book_d90.summary: The client appears ready to make a positive behavior change towards exercising in the morning, as they have already experienced the benefits and prioritize it. They have a positive attitude towards exercise and recognize its impact on their well-being.

book_d91.client_prev_utt: Well, I just knew it would make me feel better, and it really did. My therapist used to beg me to exercise. I felt like it worked better than my meds. I even slept better.
book_d91.therapist_prev_utt: Exercising keeps your energy levels up and helps to subdue the depression, keeping you in a healthier place.
book_d91.client_utt: I think that I can get up in the morning and walk around the outdoor mall near my house. It’s not that big of a deal. I just need to think about how good it’s going to make me feel.
book_d91.therapist_utt: You’re committed to making this a priority because you know how much you’ll benefit from it.
book_d91.summary: The client is ready to make a positive behavior change towards exercising, as they have experienced the benefits and are willing to take action by planning to walk in the morning. They are motivated by the positive effects on their mood and sleep.

book_d92.client_utt: All my sisters have diabetes and my mother too.
book_d92.therapist_utt: And it worries you that you’re next.
book_d92.summary: The client is expressing concern about their family history of diabetes, indicating a potential readiness to make a positive behavior change.

book_d93.client_prev_utt: All my sisters have diabetes and my mother too.
book_d93.therapist_prev_utt: And it worries you that you’re next.
book_d93.client_utt: Yes, I’m scared that if I don’t change what I’m doing now, that I’m going to get it too.
book_d93.therapist_utt: You see that there are some things you can do that might reduce your chances of developing diabetes.
book_d93.summary: The client is expressing fear and concern about developing diabetes due to their family history. They are acknowledging the need to change their current behaviors to prevent the same outcome. The client appears ready to make a positive behavior change.

book_d94.client_prev_utt: Yes, I’m scared that if I don’t change what I’m doing now, that I’m going to get it too.
book_d94.therapist_prev_utt: You see that there are some things you can do that might reduce your chances of developing diabetes.
book_d94.client_utt: I do. I think I need to quit drinking soda, for one. I go through a 12-pack a week. I think that’s where I need to start.
book_d94.therapist_utt: Once you see your goal, you don’t back down.
book_d94.summary: The client is ready to make a positive behavior change. They acknowledge the need to quit drinking soda in order to reduce their chances of developing diabetes.

book_d95.client_prev_utt: I do. I think I need to quit drinking soda, for one. I go through a 12-pack a week. I think that’s where I need to start.
book_d95.therapist_prev_utt: Once you see your goal, you don’t back down.
book_d95.client_utt: Yes, I’m a goal-driven person. I’ve always been that way.
book_d95.therapist_utt: What’s another time that you made a goal and went for it?
book_d95.summary: The client appears ready to make a positive behavior change in regards to their soda consumption, expressing a desire to quit drinking soda and acknowledging the need to start there. The client also identifies as a goal-driven person, indicating potential readiness for change.

book_d96.therapist_prev_utt: How do you feel about being physically active?
book_d96.client_utt: I know I need to exercise more. I was going for walks in the afternoon but it has been so cold lately, so I’ve stopped.
book_d96.therapist_utt: You’d like to figure out ways to be active that aren’t influenced by the weather. What other reasons, if any, caused you to stop?

sub_behaviours.reflection-simple: You’d like to figure out ways to be active that aren’t influenced by the weather.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What other reasons, if any, caused you to stop?

book_d96.summary: The client acknowledges the need to exercise more but has stopped due to the cold weather. They are open to the idea of being physically active but may need some support or motivation to overcome the barrier of the weather. The client is ready to make a positive behavior change with some encouragement.

book_d97.client_prev_utt: I know I need to exercise more. I was going for walks in the afternoon but it has been so cold lately, so I’ve stopped.
book_d97.therapist_prev_utt: You’d like to figure out ways to be active that aren’t influenced by the weather. What other reasons, if any, caused you to stop?
book_d97.client_utt: Honestly, it felt like a chore. I would just rather not.
book_d97.therapist_utt: It was something you made yourself do but you weren’t getting any enjoyment out of it. And now that the weather is better, you’re finding it hard to get going again.
book_d97.summary: The client is resistant to making a positive behavior change regarding exercise. They view it as a chore and would rather not do it.

book_d98.client_prev_utt: Honestly, it felt like a chore. I would just rather not.
book_d98.therapist_prev_utt: It was something you made yourself do but you weren’t getting any enjoyment out of it. And now that the weather is better, you’re finding it hard to get going again.
book_d98.client_utt: Yes, but I don’t know what else to do. I can’t afford to join a gym.
book_d98.therapist_utt: Money is another factor. Tell me about a time when you enjoyed being physically active, if that’s ever been the case?

sub_behaviours.reflection-simple: Money is another factor.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: Tell me about a time when you enjoyed being physically active, if that’s ever been the case?

book_d98.summary: The client appears resistant to making a positive behavior change, expressing a lack of enjoyment and motivation towards the activity. They are also feeling stuck and unsure of alternative options due to financial constraints.

book_d99.client_prev_utt: Yes, but I don’t know what else to do. I can’t afford to join a gym.
book_d99.therapist_prev_utt: Money is another factor. Tell me about a time when you enjoyed being physically active, if that’s ever been the case?
book_d99.client_utt: I used to be very active when I was younger. I’d walk for an hour in the morning just to get outside and breathe in the fresh air.
book_d99.therapist_utt: It sounds like you used to really enjoy your walks. What changed for you? Why does it feel like a chore now?

sub_behaviours.reflection-simple: It sounds like you used to really enjoy your walks.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What changed for you? Why does it feel like a chore now?

book_d99.summary: The client appears to have a positive attitude towards physical activity, as they mention enjoying being active in the past. However, they express a barrier to making a change due to financial constraints. The client may be open to making a positive behavior change if the financial barrier can be addressed.

book_d100.client_prev_utt: I used to be very active when I was younger. I’d walk for an hour in the morning just to get outside and breathe in the fresh air.
book_d100.therapist_prev_utt: It sounds like you used to really enjoy your walks. What changed for you? Why does it feel like a chore now?
book_d100.client_utt: I’m not comfortable like I used to be. I was thin then.
book_d100.therapist_utt: Exercising felt good because you weren’t self-conscious about your body. What about going for a walk makes you feel self-conscious now?

sub_behaviours.reflection-complex: Exercising felt good because you weren’t self-conscious about your body.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What about going for a walk makes you feel self-conscious now?

book_d100.summary: The client reminisces about their past active lifestyle and expresses dissatisfaction with their current physical state. They seem to be somewhat resistant to making a positive behavior change, as they attribute their lack of activity to their weight gain.

book_d101.client_prev_utt: I’m not comfortable like I used to be. I was thin then.
book_d101.therapist_prev_utt: Exercising felt good because you weren’t self-conscious about your body. What about going for a walk makes you feel self-conscious now?
book_d101.client_utt: I just feel like everyone’s looking at me and thinking about how much weight I’ve gained. I know I shouldn’t care about what they think, but it just bothers me.
book_d101.therapist_utt: You’ve stopped doing something that you used to really enjoy because you’re afraid of what people may or may not be thinking about you. What do you think about that?

sub_behaviours.reflection-complex: You’ve stopped doing something that you used to really enjoy because you’re afraid of what people may or may not be thinking about you.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What do you think about that?

book_d101.summary: The client is resistant to making a positive behavior change. They are self-conscious about their weight gain and feel like others are judging them, which is a barrier to exercising.

book_d102.client_prev_utt: I just feel like everyone’s looking at me and thinking about how much weight I’ve gained. I know I shouldn’t care about what they think, but it just bothers me.
book_d102.therapist_prev_utt: You’ve stopped doing something that you used to really enjoy because you’re afraid of what people may or may not be thinking about you. What do you think about that?
book_d102.client_utt: It sounds stupid. I really don’t even run into people I know when I go on a walk.
book_d102.therapist_utt: It doesn’t sound logical to you. I wonder if you had something else to think about or focus on while walking you wouldn’t worry about what other people are think- ing. When you used to walk, what did you like to think about?

sub_behaviours.reflection-complex: It doesn’t sound logical to you.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: I wonder if you had something else to think about or focus on while walking you wouldn’t worry about what other people are think- ing. When you used to walk, what did you like to think about?

book_d102.summary: The client is resistant to making a positive behavior change, as they acknowledge that their concern about others' opinions is irrational but still bothers them. They do not see a need to change their behavior of avoiding activities they enjoy due to this fear.

book_d103.client_prev_utt: It sounds stupid. I really don’t even run into people I know when I go on a walk.
book_d103.therapist_prev_utt: It doesn’t sound logical to you. I wonder if you had something else to think about or focus on while walking you wouldn’t worry about what other people are think- ing. When you used to walk, what did you like to think about?
book_d103.client_utt: I just liked feeling strong. I would go out in the morning when the air is crisp and push myself to do more than I did before.
book_d103.therapist_utt: You felt powerful during your walks, like you had accomplished something when you were done. I bet doing it in the morning set you up for a good day too.
book_d103.summary: The client appears resistant to making a positive behavior change, expressing skepticism and focusing on the negative aspects of walking. However, there is a glimmer of readiness as they reminisce about the positive feelings associated with walking in the past.

book_d104.client_prev_utt: I just liked feeling strong. I would go out in the morning when the air is crisp and push myself to do more than I did before.
book_d104.therapist_prev_utt: You felt powerful during your walks, like you had accomplished something when you were done. I bet doing it in the morning set you up for a good day too.
book_d104.client_utt: Yeah, it usually would. I’m far more organized when I get up in the morning. Plus I sleep better when I have a routine and make myself get up.
book_d104.therapist_utt: Working out was never really about how you looked, but more about how it made you feel. You felt powerful and accomplished; you got a jump on the day and felt more organized; plus, you slept better, giving you more energy the next day. Physical activity did a lot of positive things for you, but now the thought that people might think less of you is getting in the way of you feeling good about yourself. What do you think?

sub_behaviours.reflection-complex: Working out was never really about how you looked, but more about how it made you feel. You felt powerful and accomplished; you got a jump on the day and felt more organized; plus, you slept better, giving you more energy the next day. Physical activity did a lot of positive things for you, but now the thought that people might think less of you is getting in the way of you feeling good about yourself.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What do you think?

book_d104.summary: The client appears to be ready to make a positive behavior change, as they express enjoyment and benefits from their morning walks and routine. They acknowledge the positive impact on their organization and sleep, indicating a readiness to continue with this behavior.

book_d105.client_prev_utt: Yeah, it usually would. I’m far more organized when I get up in the morning. Plus I sleep better when I have a routine and make myself get up.
book_d105.therapist_prev_utt: Working out was never really about how you looked, but more about how it made you feel. You felt powerful and accomplished; you got a jump on the day and felt more organized; plus, you slept better, giving you more energy the next day. Physical activity did a lot of positive things for you, but now the thought that people might think less of you is getting in the way of you feeling good about yourself. What do you think?
book_d105.client_utt: I guess so. I just don’t know how to get over that hurdle. It gets in my way every time. I have really good intentions and then each time I try to do it, it gets harder and harder.
book_d105.therapist_utt: You’re looking for ways to overcome those hurdles. I have some ideas if you’d like to hear them.

sub_behaviours.reflection-simple: You’re looking for ways to overcome those hurdles.
sub_behaviours.seek-collaboration: I have some ideas if you’d like to hear them.

book_d105.summary: The client is showing some readiness to make a positive behavior change, as they acknowledge the benefits of physical activity and express frustration with the obstacle of worrying about others' opinions. However, they also express difficulty in overcoming this hurdle and maintaining their intentions.

book_d106.client_prev_utt: I guess so. I just don’t know how to get over that hurdle. It gets in my way every time. I have really good intentions and then each time I try to do it, it gets harder and harder.
book_d106.therapist_prev_utt: You’re looking for ways to overcome those hurdles. I have some ideas if you’d like to hear them.
book_d106.therapist_utt: People tend to feel inspired to exercise when they focus on the way being active makes them feel. You might find you enjoy it more when you are more focused on how you feel instead of los- ing weight. Some things to notice might be your breathing, how your muscles move, and how your energy level increases. Just like before, you would smell the crisp air and enjoy your surroundings in the morning. What do you think of this information?

sub_behaviours.give-information: People tend to feel inspired to exercise when they focus on the way being active makes them feel. You might find you enjoy it more when you are more focused on how you feel instead of los- ing weight. Some things to notice might be your breathing, how your muscles move, and how your energy level increases. Just like before, you would smell the crisp air and enjoy your surroundings in the morning.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What do you think of this information?

book_d106.summary: The client appears to be ready to make a positive behavior change, as they express frustration with the obstacles in their way and are open to hearing ideas for overcoming them.

book_d107.therapist_prev_utt: People tend to feel inspired to exercise when they focus on the way being active makes them feel. You might find you enjoy it more when you are more focused on how you feel instead of los- ing weight. Some things to notice might be your breathing, how your muscles move, and how your energy level increases. Just like before, you would smell the crisp air and enjoy your surroundings in the morning. What do you think of this information?
book_d107.client_utt: I like that. I think I have been too wrapped up in my head that I’m not enjoying the process. It might even be fun to call up one of my girlfriends and ask her to go with me.
book_d107.therapist_utt: Going with a friend can help you get started again.
book_d107.summary: The client seems ready to make a positive behavior change in regards to exercising. They express interest in focusing on how exercise makes them feel and are open to trying new strategies, such as exercising with a friend.

book_d108.therapist_prev_utt: Some of my clients have found it helpful to set up a reward system when getting started with a new activity plan. Would you be interested in hearing more about this strategy?
book_d108.therapist_utt: There are many ways to do it, and you can decide what might work best for you. One way is to set a weekly goal such as going for a walk three days a week. And then for each week you are successful in reaching that goal, you treat yourself to an inexpensive reward, such as a magazine in the grocery store checkout line or downloading a new song to listen to. Others prefer setting up rewards based on total minutes or steps per week or per month. What do you think of this approach?

sub_behaviours.emphasize-autonomy: There are many ways to do it, and you can decide what might work best for you.
sub_behaviours.give-information: One way is to set a weekly goal such as going for a walk three days a week. And then for each week you are successful in reaching that goal, you treat yourself to an inexpensive reward, such as a magazine in the grocery store checkout line or downloading a new song to listen to. Others prefer setting up rewards based on total minutes or steps per week or per month.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What do you think of this approach?

book_d108.summary: The client appears open to exploring new strategies for behavior change and is willing to consider implementing a reward system. They seem ready to make a positive behavior change.

book_d109.therapist_prev_utt: There are many ways to do it, and you can decide what might work best for you. One way is to set a weekly goal such as going for a walk three days a week. And then for each week you are successful in reaching that goal, you treat yourself to an inexpensive reward, such as a magazine in the grocery store checkout line or downloading a new song to listen to. Others prefer setting up rewards based on total minutes or steps per week or per month. What do you think of this approach?
book_d109.client_utt: I like that. I love going to the movies, so I think I’ll take myself to the movies at the end of the month if I’ve met my monthly goal. Maybe I could set a monthly goal of going for a walk 12 times.
book_d109.therapist_utt: You found something that could get you excited about your new plan.
book_d109.summary: The client appears ready and motivated to make a positive behavior change. They are open to setting goals and rewards for themselves to help achieve their desired outcome.

book_d110.therapist_prev_utt: It says here that you are physically active once a week, and you’ve written in the margin “if I’m lucky.” What do you mean by “if I’m lucky”?
book_d110.client_utt: Well, I have a lot going on. If everything comes together I’ll be able to steal away to the gym for a while. But it rarely happens. I used to go three to five times a week before my husband and I had our kids.
book_d110.therapist_utt: You have a pretty hectic schedule, which tends to push getting to the gym to the end of the list.
book_d110.summary: The client appears to have some ambivalence towards increasing their physical activity, as they acknowledge the barriers but also express a desire to return to their previous routine. They may be in the contemplation stage of change, considering the benefits of being more physically active but struggling with the practicalities of fitting it into their current lifestyle.

book_d111.client_prev_utt: Well, I have a lot going on. If everything comes together I’ll be able to steal away to the gym for a while. But it rarely happens. I used to go three to five times a week before my husband and I had our kids.
book_d111.therapist_prev_utt: You have a pretty hectic schedule, which tends to push getting to the gym to the end of the list.
book_d111.client_utt: It’s not that it’s not a priority for me. It’s just that when I’m home in the evenings and the kids get home it’s all homework and dinner. There’s always something else that needs my attention.
book_d111.therapist_utt: Physical activity would need to be something that fits easier into your life and involve your family. If you were to start doing more activities that didn’t impose on your family life, what would they be?

sub_behaviours.reflection-simple: Physical activity would need to be something that fits easier into your life and involve your family.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: If you were to start doing more activities that didn’t impose on your family life, what would they be?

book_d111.summary: The client is expressing a desire to go to the gym but is struggling to find the time due to a busy schedule and family responsibilities. They seem open to the idea of making a positive behavior change but are currently facing barriers that make it difficult to prioritize exercise.

book_d112.client_prev_utt: It’s not that it’s not a priority for me. It’s just that when I’m home in the evenings and the kids get home it’s all homework and dinner. There’s always something else that needs my attention.
book_d112.therapist_prev_utt: Physical activity would need to be something that fits easier into your life and involve your family. If you were to start doing more activities that didn’t impose on your family life, what would they be?
book_d112.client_utt: Well, sometimes I take our dog for a walk. It’s usually my son’s responsibility, but I do it when he’s too busy with homework. Sometimes we do it together, but I don’t break a sweat.
book_d112.therapist_utt: Since you don’t break a sweat, you’re wondering if it still counts.
book_d112.summary: The client is resistant to making a positive behavior change towards physical activity. They acknowledge that it is not a priority for them and cite family responsibilities as a barrier to engaging in physical activity.

book_d113.client_prev_utt: Well, sometimes I take our dog for a walk. It’s usually my son’s responsibility, but I do it when he’s too busy with homework. Sometimes we do it together, but I don’t break a sweat.
book_d113.therapist_prev_utt: Since you don’t break a sweat, you’re wondering if it still counts.
book_d113.client_utt: It’s just not the same as when I work out. We’re just walking around and having fun.
book_d113.therapist_utt: And when you think of exercise, you don’t think about having fun.
book_d113.summary: The client is resistant to making a positive behavior change. They do not see walking the dog as a sufficient form of exercise and do not feel motivated to break a sweat during the activity.

book_d114.therapist_prev_utt: Hi, Ted, what brings you in to see me today?
book_d114.client_utt: My doctor told me to come see you. The last couple times I’ve seen him, he’s been on me about my cholesterol. He thinks some exercise will help.
book_d114.therapist_utt: Your doctor is concerned about your cholesterol and had recommended you do some physical activity to help get it down. What do you think about that plan?

sub_behaviours.reflection-simple: Your doctor is concerned about your cholesterol and had recommended you do some physical activity to help get it down.
sub_behaviours.question-open-focusing: What do you think about that plan?

book_d114.summary: The client appears open to the idea of making a positive behavior change in response to their doctor's recommendation for exercise to improve their cholesterol levels. They seem ready to take action towards improving their health.

book_d115.client_prev_utt: My doctor told me to come see you. The last couple times I’ve seen him, he’s been on me about my cholesterol. He thinks some exercise will help.
book_d115.therapist_prev_utt: Your doctor is concerned about your cholesterol and had recommended you do some physical activity to help get it down. What do you think about that plan?
book_d115.client_utt: I think it’s a great idea. I used to be pretty fit, but lately I’ve just gotten out of the habit.

book_d115.summary: The client appears ready to make a positive behavior change in regards to their physical activity. They acknowledge the benefits of exercise and express a willingness to get back into the habit.

book_d116.client_prev_utt: I think it’s a great idea. I used to be pretty fit, but lately I’ve just gotten out of the habit.
book_d116.therapist_prev_utt: You’re pretty excited to get started and feel the way you used to when you were in shape.

book_d122.client_utt: What do you have in mind?
book_d122.therapist_utt: One idea is to take this week and go through the motions to make sure you’ve got everything set up right. Maybe just put on your clothes at work and head to the park. Then maybe next week, after you’ve played around with this part of the goal, you could set a certain number of min- utes or laps that line up with your current fitness level. Some of my clients have found it useful to use this fitness journal when get- ting started to write down your activity and how it feels each time you go. What do you think?

w6_u1.client_utt: I've been worried about how much time I spend sitting. Can it really be that bad for me?
w6_u1.therapist_utt: Yes, studies have shown that being inactive is linked to being overweight and obese, type 2 diabetes, some types of cancer, and even early death. Sitting for long periods can slow your metabolism, affecting your body's ability to regulate blood sugar, blood pressure, and break down body fat. Given this information about the risks of inactivity, I'm wondering what you make of it?

w8_u1.client_utt: I've heard that exercising regularly can prevent some health issues. Is that true?
w8_u1.therapist_utt: Yes, it is. People who exercise regularly have a lower risk of developing chronic conditions like heart disease, type 2 diabetes, stroke, and some cancers.

sub_behaviours.give-information: People who exercise regularly have a lower risk of developing chronic conditions like heart disease, type 2 diabetes, stroke, and some cancers.

w9_u1.client_utt: Are there other benefits of being active?
w9_u1.therapist_utt: Absolutely. Your interest in learning more about the benefits of physical activity is commendable – it shows you're taking a proactive approach to your health. Research shows that physical activity can boost your self-esteem, mood, sleep quality, and energy levels. It can also reduce your risk of stress, clinical depression, dementia, and Alzheimer's disease.

w10_u1.client_utt: I've been hearing a lot about the importance of being active every day. How much activity should I be aiming for each week?
w10_u1.therapist_utt: According to the UK Chief Medical Officers' Physical Activity Guidelines, adults should try to be active every day and aim for at least 150 minutes of physical activity over the week. This should include a variety of activities.

w10_u3.client_utt: How intense does the activity need to be?
w10_u3.therapist_utt: For an activity to benefit your health, you need to move quickly enough to raise your heart rate, breathe faster, and feel warmer. This is known as moderate intensity activity. You should still be able to talk, but not sing the words to a song. Vigorous intensity activity, where you're breathing hard and fast and your heart rate is significantly higher, can bring even greater health benefits. At this level, you won't be able to say more than a few words without pausing for breath. Before we go further, I'm curious to hear your thoughts on these different intensity levels. Is there one that seems more achievable or appealing to you right now?

w13_u1.client_utt: I've been thinking about starting to exercise, but I'm not sure what activities would count as moderate intensity. Can you help me understand?
w13_u1.therapist_utt: Before I explain, would you like to share what you currently understand about moderate intensity activities? That way, I can tailor my explanation to your needs. Moderate intensity activities are those that raise your heart rate, make you breathe faster, and make you feel warmer, but you can still carry on a conversation without being out of breath. Examples include brisk walking, riding a bike, dancing, playing doubles tennis, and even pushing a lawn mower.

w14_u1.client_utt: I've been thinking about stepping up my exercise routine. What exactly counts as vigorous intensity activity?
w14_u1.therapist_utt: Vigorous intensity activities are those that make you breathe hard and fast. If you're working at this level, you'll find it difficult to say more than a few words without pausing for breath. Examples include running, swimming, cycling fast or uphill, playing sports like football or rugby, skipping, aerobics, and martial arts.

w15_u1.client_utt: I've heard that strength exercises are important for overall fitness. What exactly counts as a strength exercise?
w15_u1.therapist_utt: Strength exercises are activities that make your muscles work harder than usual. They help to increase muscle strength, size, power, and endurance. These activities typically involve using your body weight or working against a resistance.

w17_u3.client_utt: I've heard about yoga and pilates but I'm not sure which one would be better for me. Can you explain the difference?
w17_u3.therapist_utt: Yoga involves holding poses that focus on stretching and strengthening various muscle groups, while also emphasizing breath control and relaxation. Pilates, on the other hand, focuses on core strength, flexibility, and body awareness through controlled movements. Both can be beneficial for improving flexibility, so it often comes down to personal preference and what feels best for your body.

w34_u1.client_utt: I've been reading about different types of physical activity, but I'm a bit confused. What kinds of activities should I focus on?
w34_u1.therapist_utt: That's a good question. Experts recommend two main types of physical activities: aerobic and muscle-strengthening activities.

w34_u2.client_prev_utt: I've been reading about different types of physical activity, but I'm a bit confused. What kinds of activities should I focus on?
w34_u2.therapist_prev_utt: That's a good question. Experts recommend two main types of physical activities: aerobic and muscle-strengthening activities.
w34_u2.client_utt: Can you explain what aerobic activities are?
w34_u2.therapist_utt: Sure. Aerobic activities, also known as endurance or cardio activities, involve using your large muscle groups like your chest, legs, and back. These activities help to speed up your heart rate and breathing. Examples include walking, running, cycling, and swimming.

w34_u3.client_prev_utt: Can you explain what aerobic activities are?
w34_u3.therapist_prev_utt: Sure. Aerobic activities, also known as endurance or cardio activities, involve using your large muscle groups like your chest, legs, and back. These activities help to speed up your heart rate and breathing. Examples include walking, running, cycling, and swimming.
w34_u3.therapist_utt: Muscle-strengthening activities, or strength training, involve working your muscles by making you push or pull against some form of resistance. This can be done using hand-held weights, an exercise bar, exercise bands, or even everyday items like soup cans. Exercises like push-ups, squats, and lifting weights are good examples.

w34_u4.client_prev_utt: Got it. What about muscle-strengthening activities?
w34_u4.therapist_prev_utt: Muscle-strengthening activities, or strength training, involve working your muscles by making you push or pull against some form of resistance. This can be done using hand-held weights, an exercise bar, exercise bands, or even everyday items like soup cans. Exercises like push-ups, squats, and lifting weights are good examples.
w34_u4.client_utt: So, I need to include both types in my routine?
w34_u4.therapist_utt: Both aerobic and muscle-strengthening activities are important for overall health. They complement each other and provide a range of benefits, from improving heart health to building muscle strength and endurance. Before we move forward, I'd like to make sure we're on the same page. What do you see as the main challenge here?

w35_u1.client_utt: I've been wondering about how much physical activity I actually need to stay healthy. Can you give me some guidelines?

w36_u2.client_utt: What kind of easy activities should I start with?
w36_u2.therapist_utt: Walking at a gentle pace is a great start. For example, you could begin by walking for 5 minutes at a time, several times a day, 5 to 6 days a week. w54_u1.client_utt: I've heard about SMART fitness goals but I'm not sure how they work. Can you explain them to me?
w54_u1.therapist_utt: SMART goals were originally introduced by business consultants in the 1980s to help employees meet their work objectives. The approach is very effective for fitness goals too.

w54_u2.client_prev_utt: I've heard about SMART fitness goals but I'm not sure how they work. Can you explain them to me?
w54_u2.therapist_prev_utt: SMART goals were originally introduced by business consultants in the 1980s to help employees meet their work objectives. The approach is very effective for fitness goals too.
w54_u2.therapist_utt: SMART goals help you approach an objective systematically and thoughtfully. For example, if a business owner’s goal is to "make more money," it doesn't tell you how they're going to do it or how much they want to make. Similarly, a fitness goal to "get healthier" isn't specific enough.

w54_u3.therapist_prev_utt: SMART goals help you approach an objective systematically and thoughtfully. For example, if a business owner’s goal is to "make more money," it doesn't tell you how they're going to do it or how much they want to make. Similarly, a fitness goal to "get healthier" isn't specific enough.
w54_u3.client_utt: So, how do I make my fitness goals SMART?
w54_u3.therapist_utt: SMART stands for Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound. Setting goals this way provides a clear plan and holds you accountable. For example, instead of saying "I want to get healthier," you could set a goal like, "I will walk for 30 minutes, five days a week."

w55_u1.client_utt: How do I make my fitness goals specific?
w55_u1.therapist_utt: A specific goal is targeted and clear. For example, instead of saying "I want to walk more," you could say "I want to improve my average number of steps per day." This gives you a clear starting point and target expectation.

w55_u2.client_prev_utt: How do I make my fitness goals specific?
w55_u2.therapist_prev_utt: A specific goal is targeted and clear. For example, instead of saying "I want to walk more," you could say "I want to improve my average number of steps per day." This gives you a clear starting point and target expectation.
w55_u2.client_utt: What about making the goal measurable?
w55_u2.therapist_utt: A measurable goal allows you to track your progress. For the steps example, you can use a pedometer or other step-counting device to monitor how many steps you take each day. This way, you can see how you're progressing toward your goal.

w56_u1.client_utt: I've been hearing a lot about SMART fitness goals, but I'm not quite sure how to make them attainable. Can you help?
w56_u1.therapist_utt: It seems like you're interested in setting effective goals but you're feeling uncertain about how to make them realistically achievable. When setting SMART goals, making them attainable is crucial. If you're new to consistent exercise, aiming to run a marathon in a month isn't realistic or advisable.

sub_behaviours.reflection-complex: It seems like you're interested in setting effective goals but you're feeling uncertain about how to make them realistically achievable.
sub_behaviours.persuade: When setting SMART goals, making them attainable is crucial. If you're new to consistent exercise, aiming to run a marathon in a month isn't realistic or advisable.

w56_u2.client_utt: How do I know if a goal is attainable for me?
w56_u2.therapist_utt: An attainable goal is one that you can realistically achieve based on your current fitness level, the time and energy you can devote, and your motivation. For instance, increasing your daily steps by an average of 2,000 is attainable for many people. It’s a significant change, but achievable with a bit of extra effort.

w62_u1.client_utt: I've heard that physical activity can benefit my health, but I'm not sure how strong the evidence is. Can you clarify?
w62_u1.therapist_utt: Absolutely. There's high certainty evidence that any level and any intensity of physical activity is associated with a lower risk of all-cause mortality and cardiovascular disease mortality. It also lowers the incidence of hypertension, cardiovascular disease, and type-2 diabetes.

w63_u1.client_utt: I've been reading about the benefits of physical activity, especially regarding cardiovascular health and hypertension. Can you tell me more about that?
w63_u1.therapist_utt: The benefits of physical activity for reducing the incidence of cardiovascular disease and hypertension are well-documented. Physical activity promotes many physiological responses that result in beneficial short- and long-term adaptations.

w63_u2.client_utt: What kind of adaptations are we talking about?
w63_u2.therapist_utt: These adaptations are autonomic and haemodynamic, which means they help regulate your body's automatic functions and blood flow. This, in turn, lowers the risk of hypertension, a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease.

w63_u3.client_prev_utt: What kind of adaptations are we talking about?

w67_u5.client_utt: This is all quite concerning. I often sit for much longer than 8 hours a day. What can I do to mitigate these risks?

w68_u2.client_prev_utt: I want to start exercising, but I'm worried about potential health risks. I've been inactive for so long, is it safe for me to just start?
w68_u2.therapist_prev_utt: It's great that you're thinking about becoming more active. Many people share your concerns. What specific worries do you have about starting to exercise?
w68_u2.client_utt: Well, I've heard about people having heart attacks when they suddenly start exercising. And I'm worried about injuring myself since I'm not used to physical activity.
w68_u2.therapist_utt: Those are understandable concerns. The good news is that for most people, it's safe to start physical activity without medical clearance. The key is to start small and gradually increase your activity level over time. Ultimately, you're the best judge of what feels right for your body, and you have the power to decide how to approach increasing your activity in a way that feels safe and comfortable for you.

w68_u3.client_prev_utt: Well, I've heard about people having heart attacks when they suddenly start exercising. And I'm worried about injuring myself since I'm not used to physical activity.
w68_u3.therapist_prev_utt: Those are understandable concerns. The good news is that for most people, it's safe to start physical activity without medical clearance. The key is to start small and gradually increase your activity level over time.
w68_u3.client_utt: Really? I don't need to see a doctor first?
w68_u3.therapist_utt: Generally, no. Inactive individuals who slowly progress to moderate-intensity activity have a very low risk of sudden cardiac events or injuries. The important thing is to start with small amounts and gradually increase the frequency, intensity, and duration.

w68_u4.client_prev_utt: Really? I don't need to see a doctor first?
w68_u4.therapist_prev_utt: Generally, no. Inactive individuals who slowly progress to moderate-intensity activity have a very low risk of sudden cardiac events or injuries. The important thing is to start with small amounts and gradually increase the frequency, intensity, and duration.
w68_u4.client_utt: That's reassuring. But what if I want to do more intense exercise eventually?
w68_u4.therapist_utt: If you're consistently doing moderate-intensity activity, you can gradually increase to vigorous-intensity without needing to consult a healthcare provider. However, if you develop any new symptoms when increasing your activity levels, you should consult a doctor. It's important that you listen to your body and make choices that align with your own comfort and readiness.

w68_u5.client_utt: Are there any situations where someone should check with a doctor before exercising?
w68_u5.therapist_utt: Yes, there are. People with chronic conditions, disabilities, or those who are pregnant might need to consult a healthcare provider or physical activity specialist. They can provide advice on appropriate types and amounts of activity based on individual needs and limitations.
